comments.commentBody:
Seriously, Rima? You are claiming that O'Reilly "aided and abetted" a criminal? Are we to expect an investigation of O'Reilly? Is an arrest imminent?

Be sure to keep us all informed of the breaking news updates courtesy of Rachel Maddow.

States like Wisconsin have done everything possible to make sure it doesn't work. Volunteers who want help people work through the sign up process are required to pay fees and take a test to qualify. It comes pretty close to sabotage. You don't suppose the Tea Party has hired somebody to hack the exchange. Nah, they wouldn't do that, would they???

It doesn't suggest that.  But sugar contributes to cavities and the question was whether it's ethical for a dentist to contribute to dental decay, especially in people who probably aren't receiving professional care.  I vote no.

In reply to jas: it's an assumption that these people aren't receiving professional medical/dental care. We don't know. All children are covered under Obamacare. But if we're making assumptions, we should also assume that their neighborhoods are likely unsafe for trick-or-treating. In this case, the sense of normalcy they might get from indulging in a few treats might outweigh the risk of future cavities (and most kids do have toothbrushes).
I was unaware that cavities could occur overnight.

The Tea Party has dishonest and seditious leaders, and followers who are incapable of recognizing their own rational self-interest.  We need something more than experience (against which they have been inoculated) to bring them to  a reasoned appreciation of our reality and our choices.

Yay: it's milk and cookies time again!  Clinton knew how to schmooze.  Dubya found everyone a silly nickname.  LBJ knew how to engage (he also knew how to step up our excellent adventure in Viet Nam).  Our incumbent President, on the other hand, has merely learned how to deal with terrorists- both in Pakistan and in Washington.  He's extended an olive branch often enough and each time he's done so it's been flung back in his face.  Sorry, Ms. Dowd: that one time that "Barry" passed you in the hallway without rushing over to invite you to tea has been tearing you apart, hasn't it?  Why it's enough to get you wishing you were covering the entertainment beat for TMZ and conducting an up-close-and-personal with Kanye West...

BTW It is illegal to pick through garbage in NYC.

It belongs to the sanitation department.

You can get arrested.

Yours would be a fool's bet. If you read the article, he said that the difference between a $100 and $1000 was demand.  One does not have to have tasted as many wines as Kermit Lynch to tell the difference between a $10 and $1000 bottle (or, for that matter, between a $10 and $100 bottle). There the difference is quality.

I've never had a thousand dollar bottle of wine but I've done a ton of double-blind taste tests with wines ranging from $5 to close to $100. While there's occasionally a decent wine under $10, there's a decent correlation between quality and price. Especially when it comes to red zin and pinot noir (though red Burgundies can be hit-or-miss, there are some not so lovely ones that are well over $50).
Give him a double blind wine tasting test, see how well he does and publish the results .I'll bet he can't tell the difference between a $10 bottle and a $1000 bottle.
HW, I believe the comments about the octopus protecting her eggs were quickly withdrawn for not being correct. I can't provide a link to the forum, but I'm pretty certain that's the case.
For this place to succeed all they need to do is open the doors and let the tourists in.

Loved reading these comments. New Yorkers must be a kinder, gentler bunch than San Franciscans. I am saddened by all the clever nastiness in the SF Chronicle's online comments. Thanks for the positivity, folks!
- (Ex West-Coaster for 9 years, now back living in Kiwiland)
What an inspiring post, Will. I wish you peace and continued progress in your life and goals.

Lewis Cass ran against Abraham Lincoln for the 1860 Republican nomination at the Wigwam in Chicago (the building Bruce Catton called "the most spectacular firetrap in America").  Cass lost the nomination of course, but was later incorporated into Lincoln's cabinet.

Anybody still up? I had a messy grid, with several write-overs: THEBUZZ @7D (thinking gossip for dirt), GOTONTO @32A, RPI @37A, SANS @ 48D. All was finally revealed, though, without Googling.

Interesting reading today's comments about pop music and other pop culture. Anyone who's been keeping score at home may have noticed that my wheelhouse for pop music is, more or less, 1955-2000. Pre-55, pretty good; post-2000, not quite as all-encompassing.

"Release the KRAKEN!" - Liam Neeson, as Zeus, "Clash of the Titans"

"Make Your Own Kind of Music", Mama CASS, 1969:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1RhriAN7jME
Not to worry, I've let Jeff know. :)

@Andrea E
The difference is that
GWB had warnings that AQ was preparing to strike the US and took no action on them.

Always a mystery to me why the states that take the most from the federal government send people to DC who want to stop government spending. What do they think is going to happen?  That THEIR checks will keep coming but everyone else's will be cut off?

"And thank YOU for "Detroiting" America with another $7 TRILLION in debt to go along with our $90,000,000,000 in unfunded liabilities"

If by "you" you mean Reagan and Bush II, then you're welcome, I guess.

On the other hand Obama's cut the deficit by about 40% since he took office. But don't let facts get in the way of blind partisanship.

Hey Mr. McDaniel, Mississippi doesn't get to decide the future of the country, whether or not you are elected. Mississippi comes in last in everything that counts, and most of us don't want to dragged down like that.

And thank you, Tea Party, for dividing and thereby weakening the Republican Party and uniting and strengthening the Democrats.

If the various factions of the GOP use the strategies and tactics on each other that they've been using in general elections, it could produce a windfall for democrats, and a rush on emergency rooms for gunshot woulds to the feet.

Republican propagandists and policy thinkers don't "persuade" voters. They anger them. That's how Republicans win, by setting off the loose canons like the beginnings of the Tea Party.

In the end, it's the votes that count.

Reaganomics teaches the economic "truth" that two plus two equals six.

Saint Ronnie proclaimed that you can cut taxes and raise spending and there will be no deficits or rising debt. And even if there are neither really matter because we are Americans living in America.

But they forgot to mention that God is way too busy watching and worrying about the NFL, college football, MLB playoffs and music award shows to be bothered with watching over America during this crisis.

And the universe will have to wait until the Cook comes back in the kitchen.
You sure did your homework guys. Very interesting reading, thanks.

Beethy has it right - I'll also note that it's absurd to claim that the Republicans are interested in negotiating with President Obama. True, the Republicans are interested in taking more unilateral concessions from President Obama - but negotiations involve giving as well as taking.

The Republicans have repeatedly proven that they will not make any concessions to the Democrats. At most, the Republicans grudgingly promise to postpone harming the nation's economy for a while - and act as though they've given the Democrats a great gift. What, then, is the basis for serious negotiations?

By oracling, Lant Pritchett casts a dark shadow over schooling of children everywhere, more of it on developing countries. Schooling is learning but a particular learning need not come from schooling. Test teachers as often as children. Children will do better. Schooling has too many collateral benefits, economic growth may not be one. Learning is a choice, schooling a desirable need. " Of the Education of Children " by Michel de Montagne written in 16th century, to my mind, continues to outlive, for pertinent reasons, any number of books on the subject. Same four letters can form dare, dear and read. If a teacher can enchant the growing minds with magic of letters and words, all aught to be happy.

@Bill

My comment didn't address healthy young people, so I don't know what Kool Aid you are talking about. Health insurance is like car insurance. It covers you in case something happens. One bad case of the flu, pneumonia or food poisoning that sends you to the emergency room can cost you between $1,000-2,000 just for that visit. If you end up being admitted, or need to have labs or radiography of some kind, then there are those costs and they can run in the hundreds or thousands. Add the cost of antibiotics, many of which aren't cheap, and your cost just for that one illness goes up. While hospitals have to treat you and the state may end up footing the bill, the liability is still the patients'. With the ACA, that same illness will likely mean a trip to the doctor's for the price of a copay, maybe a trip to the lab, for the price of a copay, and covered meds, for the price of a copay.

So, while I can understand that many young people will balk at having to insure themselves, they will end up doing so because health insurance will make sense in the same way that car insurance makes sense to everyone else.

JDKJJKNY NY:

What exactly is "less government?"

******
Here's the Wiki description:

"The Tea Party generally focuses on government reform. Among its goals are limiting the size of the federal government, reducing government spending, lowering the national debt and opposing tax increases.

To this end, Tea Party groups have protested the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP), stimulus programs such as the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA, commonly referred to as the Stimulus or The Recovery Act), cap and trade, health care reform such as the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA, also known simply as the Affordable Care Act or "Obamacare") and perceived attacks by the federal government on their 1st, 2nd, 4th and 10th Amendment rights.

Tea Party groups have also voiced support for right to work legislation as well as tighter border security, and opposed amnesty for illegal immigrants."

***

It's worth noting that the Tea Party is not involved in social issues. It considers them too divisive. ;-)

Bryan: the "train wreck of Obamacare" has already produced affordable medical insurance for at least three of my friends who didn't previously have it. Please do counter that by citing the number of people you know of who have received letters from their physicians or insurance companies informing them that on account of the ACA they will no longer be covered OR that their premiums are being raised OR that they can no longer be treated by their regular physicians.
The deficit is shrinking, partially as a result of the ACA. The government shut-down, on the other hand, had the opposite effect.
And which of those unfunded future liabilities would you like to dispose of first? Make sure to name something that would affect you personally.
Did you notice that as soon as the Republicans cried uncle (the sane ones, I mean) the war memorials in Washington reopened to the public? Funny how that worked out. Guess it wasn't "the administration" after all.
It is also possible that the freeloaders in the states without Obamacare will move to the states with Obamacare.  We can only hope.

The state exchanges are doing pretty well even in large states. States with state exchanges that roll out Obamacare successfully will fight to keep it. If the Federal exchange continues to be a disaster area, states without exchanges will be pressured by many of their citizens (including RINOS) to set them up so their states can get on board a program that is working in other states. Obamacare would be provided at the state level, and states that did not provide it would have unhealthier populations and higher ER bills.

Their leaders would have to reject Obamacare even though it was working in other states, although they could always claim that the problems were just being covered up.

Indeed.

This article is a kind of mistake (or dishonesty?) that is repeated decade after a decade, a research after a research

We notice (by looking at past data) that higher educated people have higher income, let's say by $15,000 (primarily because they hold better paying jobs). Now, let's imagine that 90% of people get high education. Will they all increase their income by $15,000? Of course, not! There are simply not enough those 'high paying ' jobs. A fast major surge in education may somewhat structurally change our economy, but certainly not enough to make education pay the way it used to be. Instead, the oversupply of highly educated people will suppress the pay rate for professions that require such education.

So, before one offers such a 'solution', (s)he should think it through. It will take much more to restore the middle class than just reducing the number of administrators

Third Way is a fraud. The writers' prescription doesn't stand up to examination any better than the Right's dogma that lowering taxes creates jobs. Their proposed changes in education may be necessary, but they are grossly insufficient to solve income inequality. (And reading between the lines, they obviously favor the increasing casualization of academic labor through adjunct professorships that is strangling the pipeline that supplies the next generation of faculty).

Does it not occur to them that the demand for higher education is largely driven by the poor job market? Or that producing more graduates in a poor job market just postpones their unemployment or, at best, employs most of them at pay levels insufficient to handle college debts?

The authors' assumptions about education's benefits may have worked once, but not in the current free-for-all global economy, when the interests of capital are supreme and other considerations nowhere in sight. The destruction of blue-collar jobs came early but, combined with the technology revolution, the primacy of capital has spread the export and elimination of jobs to ever-higher levels. The trend is towards an executive class that will survive come what may, a handsomely rewarded technology elite, and masses of people (including the highly educated) who scramble between service jobs and unemployment. Education alone won't handle that. It will take a better economic model.

DRNew England

Andrea E - It's funny that you missed the money the Koch brothers poured into politics:

***
So the money they spend on politics makes their millions in philanthropic donations...worthless?

"Don't let schooling get in the way your education" is probably an older saying than I am, and it is sooo relevant, especially in the United States. The kids get schooling, but not much education. I have two in G&T programs in the better public schools and the level of challenge is appalling. They come out half ignorant, babied and not taught how to think. The Board of Ed is the biggest fraud there is. They are not concerned about education, they play with performance numbers. If .05% more graduate from high school, they pet themselves on the head, not overly concerned that that .05% and the other 80% are pathetically poorly prepared for higher level education.
Statistics, not education is the Board of Ed's primary concern. They probably don't even know what education is. Most of them never had it.
